title: 115_s1072
content: The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans and establishes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to fund legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness across various regions in the United States. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, including housing, family law, income support, and criminal defense. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, including defense in matters related to outstanding warrants, fines, and driver's license revocation to reduce recidivism and facilitate reentry obstacles in employment or housing. The Secretary may also require entities in partnerships to submit reports. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Partnerships must submit periodic reports on services provided to the Secretary. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant title. Expansion of VA's authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Expansion of VA's authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to extend eligibility for care to veterans enrolled under section 1705(a) receiving housing assistance or care in specified settings for 60 consecutive days. The Secretary may provide funds for a grant and per diem provider for homeless veterans. The Secretary can overlook breaks in care for which the veteran is not responsible when determining if they have received assistance for 60 consecutive days. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions. Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code, is amended by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d). SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. Section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code is amended to allocate $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2017. Additionally, paragraph 3 is amended to include training entities for provision of supportive services through 2017. A requirement is set for the Comptroller General to study Department of Veterans Affairs homeless veterans programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on Department of Veterans Affairs programs assisting homeless veterans within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The study will assess program effectiveness for eligible veterans and review efforts to enhance privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. Additionally, the requirement for annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans is repealed. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, is repealed, and the corresponding item in the table of sections is removed.
